text.p: Taiwan share prices are expected to consolidate on Tuesday after Monday's strong rebound but with slow, cautious turnover, brokers said.

But the market should gain support from a statement by deputy central bank governor Hsu Chia-tung on Monday that the central bank, which has tried to cool the island's recent stock market fever, would like to see "appropriate" growth.
On Monday, the index ended up 119.62 points or 1.44 percent at 8,421.87, a rebound after five straight sessions of falls.
A 8,350-8,500 range was seen for Tuesday.
"In theory, a strong rebound with slower turnover usually will lead to selling pressure in the following day," said National Securities international sales chief Oliver Fang.
"But deputy governor Hsu's saying the bank is happy to see appropriate market growth should help boost sentiment," Fang said.
He said he expected the consolidation to continue until the end of April, and investors will likely step to the sidelines in the near term.
